facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 678-680 of 1962 appealed from judgment dated March 2, 1960 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Income-tax Reference No. 6-D of 1957

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No. 678-680 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment dated March 2, 1960 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Income-tax Reference No. 6-D of 1957. C. Setalvad. Bishan Narain, R.J. Kolah and K.L. Hathi, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 9, 1963 by Sarkar J with separate opinion by Hidayatullah J

anchor.surface_text: December 9, 1963. The Judgment of A.K. Sarkar, and J.C. Shah, JJ. was delivered by Sarkar, J. M. Hidayatullah,J. delivered a separate opinion. SARKAR, J.-We think that these appeals should be allowed.

facts.text: Appeals relate to assessment to income-tax of income of life insurance business of Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd. now merged in Life Insurance Corporation Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR, J.-We think that these appeals should be allowed. The appeals relate to the assessment to incometax of the income of the life insurance business of the Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd. number merged in the Life Insurance Corporation Ltd.

facts.text: Assessment years concerned are 1952-53, 1953-54 and 1954-55

anchor.surface_text: The assessment years companycerned are 1952- 53, 1953-54 and 1954-55. The Income-tax Act, 1922 makes special provision for assessment of the income of insurance business.

facts.text: Assessee debited Rs. 18,75,000 to Consolidated Revenue Account and credited to Investment Reserve Fund

anchor.surface_text: What had happened was this. The assessee had debited a sum of Rs. 18,75,000 to its Consolidated Revenue Account and credited it to the Investment Reserve Fund. There is numberdispute that the assessee had to maintain the Investment Reserve Fund.

facts.text: Transfer to Investment Reserve Fund because securities depreciated making fund inadequate

anchor.surface_text: The transfer had been made because the assessee thought that the securities in respect of which the Investment Reserve Fund had been companystituted having depreciated the fund had become inadequate.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer directed reduction of transfer from Revenue Account to Investment Reserve Fund by Rs. 1,75,000

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, directed that the transfer from the Revenue Account to the Investment Reserve Fund be reduced by Rs. 1,75,000. The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner directed reduction of transfer by Rs. 1,45,000

anchor.surface_text: and lie directed that the transfer to the Investment Reserve Fund be reduced by Rs. 1,45,000 instead of Rs. 1,75,000. On a further appeal by the assessee to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal,

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held adjustment could only be made under proviso to r. 3(b) requiring prior consultation with Controller of Insurance which was not done, so illegal

anchor.surface_text: it was held that the adjustment companyld only be made under the proviso to r. 3 b  of the Schedule and that that rule required a prior companysultation with the Controller of Insurance, and as that had number been made, the adjustment was wholly illegal.

facts.text: Tribunal ordered transfer of Rs. 18,75,000 to be accepted as a whole

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, therefore, ordered that the transfer of Rs. 18,75,000 made by the assessee as aforesaid had to be accepted as a whole.

facts.text: Punjab High Court answered question in affirmative that Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to make adjustment in terms of r. 3(b)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, answered the question in the affirmative. The present appeals are against this judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Corresponding years of account were calendar years 1951, 1952 and 1953

anchor.surface_text: The appeals relate to assessment years 1952-53, 1953-54, and 1954-55, and the companyresponding years of account were the calendar years 1951, 1952 and 1953.

facts.text: Last inter-valuation period of four years ending December 31, 1951 accepted by Controller of Insurance

anchor.surface_text: on the basis of the annual average of the surplus of the insurance companypany as found by actuarial valuation in the last intervaluation period of four years ending on December 31, 1951 and accepted by the Controller of Insurance under the Insurance Act, 1938.

facts.text: Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd. debited Rs. 18,75,000 in consolidated revenue account from January 1, 1948 to December 31, 1951 transferred to investment reserve fund

anchor.surface_text: In this quadrennium, the Bharat Insurance Co., Ltd. had debited a sum of Rs. 18,75,000 in the companysolidated revenue account from January 1, 1948 to December 31, 1951 and had transferred the same to the investment reserve fund

facts.text: Income-tax Officer found securities undervalued by Rs. 1,58,756 and investment reserve fund excess by Rs. 30,420 total Rs. 1,89,186 disallowed Rs. 1,75,000 added to surplus

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer companypared the book value and the market value of the stocks and shares and found that that insurance companypany had under-valued certain shares and securities by Rs. 1,58,756 in the aggregate, and increased the investment reserve fund by a sum of Rs. 30,420 which was number required.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner reduced excess to Rs. 1,61,770 and disallowance to Rs. 1,45,000

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner reduced the figure of Rs. 1,89,186 to Rs. 1,61,770. He also reduced the amount of Rs. 1,75,000 to Rs. 1,45,000.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal order dated October 23, 1956 set aside adjustments for lack of consultation with Controller of Insurance

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held by its order dated October 23, 1956 as follows ... The adjustments made by the Income-tax Officer on this account are, therefore, set aside.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation took over assets and liabilities of Bharat Insurance Co. from July 6, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Life In- surance Corporation, by virtue of a numberification of the Government of India under s. 45 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956, took over from July 6, 1960 the assets and liabilities of the insurance companypany

facts.text: Actuarial valuation assumed rate of interest at 3% per annum

anchor.surface_text: The valuation abstract prepared under the fourth schedule showed that the actuary had. assumed the rate of-. interest at 3 per annum

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Income-tax Officer had no power to make the adjustments

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the decision of the High Court is clearly erroneous. ... The result, therefore, is that we find numberhing in the rules justifying the adjustment made by the Income-tax Officer in the present cases.

The Income-tax Act, 1922 makes special provision for assessment of the income of insurance business. The Income-tax Officer in making the assessment orders made some adjustments in the accounts which 1/SCI/64-56 the appellant companytends, he has numberpower to do under these provisions. The question in these appeals is whether he had the power to make these adjustments. Sub-section  7  of s. 10 of the Act makes the special provision for the assessment of the income of insurance business and that is in these terms Notwithstanding anything to the companytrary companytained in Section 8, 9, 10, 12 or 18, the profits and gains of any business of insurance and the tax payable thereon shall be companyputed in accordance with the rules companytained in the Schedule to this Act.

concepts.interpretation: Makes special provision overriding ss.8,9,10,12,18 for computing profits of insurance business strictly as per rules in the Schedule; no other adjustments permitted.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: cial provision for the assessment of the income of insurance business and that is in these terms Notwithstanding anything to the companytrary companyt

concepts.unlisted_description: Special provision for assessment of insurance business profits via Schedule rules.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 2 in the Schedule lays down in clauses  a  and  b  two different methods for calculating the profits and gains of a life insurance business and provides that whichever of these two methods results in larger profits being arrived at, has to be adopted. The relevant portion of r. 2 is in these terms Rule 2. The profits and gains of life insurance business shall be taken to be either-  a  the gross external incomings of the preceding year from that business less the management expenses of that year, or  b  the annual average of the surplus arrived at by adjusting the surplus or deficit disclosed by the actuarial valuation made in accordance with the Insurance Act, 1938  IV of 1938  in respect of the last inter-valuation period ending before the year for which the assessment is to be made so as to exclude from it any surplus or deficit included therein which was made in any earlier inter-valuation period and any expenditure other than expenditure which may under the provisions of s. 10 of this Act be allowed for in companyputing the profits and gains of a business, whichever is the greater Then follows a proviso which sets out a certain limit for management expenses to be allowed but that is number material for this judgment.

concepts.interpretation: Profits taken as greater of cl.(a) gross incomings less expenses or cl.(b) annual average surplus from actuarial valuation adjusted to exclude prior surpluses/deficits and non-allowable expenses; ITO must follow cl.(b) if larger, limited adjustments only.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ransfer made the balance in the Investment Reserve Fund exceed the deficit disclosed on the book values of the securities in that fund by Rs. 30,420.

concepts.unlisted_description: Methods to compute life insurance profits; adopt higher figure.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of r. 3 of the Schedule on which the arguments in these cases turn may number be set out. Rule 3. In companyputing the surplus for the pur- pose of rule 2,-  a   b any amount either written off or reserved in the accounts or through the actuarial valuation balance sheet to meet depreciation of or loss on the realisation of securities or other assets shall be allowed as a deduction, and any sums taken credit for in the accounts or actuarial valuation balance sheet on account of appreciation of or gains on the realisation of the securities or other assets shall be included in the surplus Provided that if upon investigation it appears to the Income-tax Officer after companysultation with the Controller of Insurance that having due regard to the necessity for making reasonable provision for bonuses to participating policy-holders and for companytingencies, the rate of interest or other factor employed in determining the liability in respect of outstanding policies is materially inconsistent with the valuation of the securities and other assets so as artifi- cially to reduce the surplus, such adjustment shall be made to the allowance for depreciation of, or to the amount to be included in the surplus in respect of appreciation of, such securities and other assets, as shall increase the surplus for the purposes of these rules to a figure which is fair and just

concepts.interpretation: Obligatory to allow deductions for depreciation/loss reserved in accounts/actuarial sheet and include appreciations; proviso permits adjustment only after ITO investigation and consultation with Controller if interest rate/other factor inconsistent with asset valuation artificially reducing surplus, considering bonuses/contingencies, to fair figure.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the securities and other assets so as artifi- cially to reduce the surplus, such adjustment shall be made to the allowance for depreciation of, or to

concepts.unlisted_description: Computation of surplus: deductions for depreciation, inclusions for appreciation; proviso for specific adjustments.

concepts.interpretation: Requires prior consultation with Controller of Insurance for adjustments; without it, adjustment illegal.

anchor.surface_text: These are three appeals by certificate granted by the High Court of Punjab under s. 66 A  of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Life In- surance Corporation, by virtue of a numberification of the Government of India under s. 45 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956, took over from July 6, 1960 the assets and liabilities of the insurance companypany

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation, in the circumstances, was substituted as the appellant in place of the insurance companypany under s. 9 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act.

By s. II of the Insurance Act, every insurer in India and every foreign insurer in respect of the insurance business transacted by him in India is required to prepare at the expiration of each calendar year with reference to that year  a  a balance sheet,  b  a profit and loss account and  c  a revenue account.

concepts.interpretation: Requires preparation of balance sheet, P&L, revenue account annually.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 13 of the Insurance Act, every insurer, carrying on life insurance business, is required, at intervals of number less than 3 years, to cause an actuarial investi- gation to be made into the financial companydition of life insurance business carried on by him, including a valuation of its liabilities in respect of that business.

concepts.interpretation: Requires actuarial investigation every 3+ years for life insurance.

issues.text: The question in these appeals is whether he had the power to make these adjustments.

anchor.surface_text: The question in these appeals is whether he had the power to make these adjustments.

issues.text: Whether upon the facts found by the Tribunal, the Income-tax Officer had in this case jurisdiction to proceed to make adjustment in terms of r. 3 b  of the Schedule to the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether upon the facts found by the Tribunal, the Income-tax Officer had in this case jurisdiction to proceed to make adjustment in terms of r. 3 b  of the Schedule to the Indian Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether the proviso to Rule 3 b , Schedule to Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 was applicable and whether the Income-tax Officer was bound to consult the Controller of Insurance in this case where no question arose about the rate of interest or other factor employed in determining the liability in respect of outstanding policies ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the proviso to Rule 3 b , Schedule to Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 was applicable and whether the Income-tax Officer was bound to consult the Controller of Insurance in this case where no question arose about the rate of interest or other factor employed in determining the liability in respect of outstanding policies ?

issues.text: Is there a general right to correct the errors in the accounts of an insurance company when assessing the income-tax?

anchor.surface_text: The only other question is, Is there a general right to correct the errors in the accounts of an insurance company when assessing the income-tax?

arguments.claim: The adjustment could only be made under the proviso to r. 3(b) of the Schedule which required prior consultation with the Controller of Insurance, and as that had not been made, the adjustment was wholly illegal.

anchor.surface_text: it was held that the adjustment could only be made under the proviso to r. 3 b  of the Schedule and that that rule required a prior consultation with the Controller of Insurance, and as that had not been made, the adjustment was wholly illegal.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees that proviso requires consultation and adjustment not fitting main rule or proviso.

arguments.claim: The Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to make adjustment in terms of r. 3(b) without consultation as the matter did not come within r. 3(b) and proviso not applicable to undervaluation for tax evasion.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the matter did not come within r. 3 b  of the Schedule and, therefore, no question of consultation with the Controller of Insurance arose. In the High Courts opinion the Income-tax Officer had not been deprived...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e. Quite clearly the adjustment made in the present case by the Income-tax Officer was number of the variety mentioned in the proviso. He does number

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erroneous; no general power outside rules; adjustment neither under main r.3(b) nor proviso.

arguments.claim: Income-tax Officer has no power to make adjustments outside the specific provisions of the Schedule rules.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer in making the assessment orders made some adjustments in the accounts which the appellant contends, he has no power to do under these provisions. The question in these appeals is whether he had the power to make these adjustments.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecial provision for the assessment of the income of insurance business and that is in these terms Notwithstanding anything to the companytrary company

arguments.court_reasoning: Rules strictly limit computations; no general power to adjust actuarial surplus except as specified.

arguments.claim: There is a general right to correct errors in accounts of insurance company when assessing income-tax, independent of r.3(b).

anchor.surface_text: The only other question is, Is there a general right to correct the errors in the accounts of an insurance company when assessing the income-tax? The High Court thought there was.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: de on the original appellant Bharat Insurance Co., Ltd. by the Income-tax Officer, Companies Circle, New Delhi under the rules framed for assess- ment

arguments.court_reasoning: No general power; assessment governed completely by Schedule rules; tampering affects insurance regulation.

arguments.claim: Under r.2(b), ITO must accept actuarial surplus as adjusted only for prior periods and s.10 expenses; no power to revalue securities.

anchor.surface_text: Under r. 2 of the Schedule the Income- tax Officer has to compute the profits and gains of a life insurance company at the greater of the two methods... He has to accept the annual average of the surplus disclosed by the actuarial valuation...

arguments.claim: Main part of r.3(b) obliges ITO to allow assessee's reservations for depreciation and include appreciations; does not permit ITO revaluation.

anchor.surface_text: This part of the rule only compels the Income-tax Officer to allow certain amounts as deductions and to include certain amounts for which credit had been taken in the accounts of the assessee. It, therefore, does not warrant what the income-tax Officer did...

arguments.claim: Proviso to r.3(b) permits adjustment only if rate of interest/other factor inconsistent with asset valuation artificially reducing surplus, after consultation.

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the proviso in r. 3 b . It says that if it appears to the Income-tax Officer... that the rate of interest or other factor employed in determining the liability... is materially inconsistent with the valuation of the securities...

arguments.claim: Present adjustment not under proviso as not related to interest rate inconsistency but undervaluation; no consultation.

anchor.surface_text: Quite clearly the adjustment made in the present case by the Income-tax Officer was not of the variety mentioned in the proviso. He does not say that he made the adjustment because he found that any rate of interest was inconsistent...

arguments.claim: No provision in rules authorizes ITO adjustments in actuarial valuation apart from r.3(b); nothing justifies this adjustment.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that we find nothing in the rules justifying the adjustment made by the Income-tax Officer in the present cases. We have set out the relevant provisions and we think that they do not contemplate any other adjustment...

arguments.claim: Action only under proviso in strict terms; reducing reserve disturbs policy liabilities and bonuses.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad... contended that action could only be taken under the proviso and in accordance with its strict terms. He submitted that by merely reducing the amounts transferred to the investment reserve fund the Income-tax Officer could not increase the surplus...

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees proviso limits power; main rule mandatory on book entries only.

arguments.claim: General power in ITO from main r.3(b) independent of proviso to adjust based on market value and disallow excess deduction.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Department, Mr. Gopal Singh contended that there was a general power in the Income-tax Officer derived from the main rule 3 b  and independent of the proviso to make such an adjustment...

arguments.court_reasoning: No general power; main rule follows book entries mandatorily; proviso only for discrepancies.

arguments.claim: Proviso to r.3(b) not applicable where no issue of interest rate; consultation not required for correcting undervaluation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso not followed and not applicable here; but no power even under main rule.

arguments.claim: Main r.3(b) allows ITO to fix permissible deductions based on correct valuation without proviso consultation.

anchor.surface_text: ...the main rule allowed the Income-tax Officer to fix the amounts of permissible deductions on the basis of a correct valuation of the securities and the Income-tax Officers jurisdiction in this respect was not in any way controlled.

arguments.court_reasoning: Main rule mandatory, no discretion to revalue; proviso governs discrepancies.

arguments.claim: If ITO doubts accounts, must proceed under proviso after consultation; no general power independent of proviso.
Precedent under old r.30 not applicable as new r.3(b) added proviso limiting power.

anchor.surface_text: They referred to the decision of the Bombay High Court in Western India Life Insurance Co. Ltd... and observed that such action was held permissible under rule 30 of the superseded rules which they held was in pari materia...

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule materially altered by proviso; old cases not precedents.

arguments.claim: Proviso negatives general power; adjustment only per proviso or not at all.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer had no power to make the adjustments to the actuarial surplus on the basis of revaluation of securities as he did in these cases.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the decision of the High Court is clearly erroneous. Under r. 2 of the Schedule the Income- tax Officer has to compute the profits and gains of a life insurance company at the greater of the two methods of assessments mentioned in cls. a and b . There may be no restriction upon his jurisdiction in the computation of profits and gains under cl. a but under cl. b the computation can be made within a limited field.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 10(7) mandates computation strictly per Schedule rules; r.2(b) requires accepting adjusted actuarial surplus without revaluation; no other provision authorizes such adjustment.

holdings.text: The adjustment made does not fall within the main part of r.3(b) which obligatorily allows deductions/reservations as per assessee's accounts and includes credits taken, without power to revalue.

anchor.surface_text: When we come to r. 3 b we find that the first part of it lays down that it shall be obligatory on the Income-tax Officer to allow certain amounts written off or reserved by the assessee as a deduction and to include in the surplus any sums for which credit has been taken on account of appreciation or gains on the realisation of the securities or other assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Main r.3(b) compels ITO to follow book entries mandatorily; does not permit independent revaluation by ITO.

holdings.text: The adjustment does not fall within the proviso to r.3(b) as it was not based on inconsistency between interest rate/other factors and asset valuation artificially reducing surplus, and no consultation with Controller of Insurance was done.

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the proviso in r. 3 b . It says that if it appears to the Income-tax Officer having regard to certain matters to which it is not necessary to refer here in detail, that the rate of interest or other factor employed in determining the liability in respect of outstanding policies is materially inconsistent with the valuation of the securities and other assets so as artificially to reduce the surplus,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso narrowly applies only to specific inconsistency after investigation and mandatory consultation; facts here involve mere undervaluation, not covered.

holdings.text: There is no general power in the Income-tax Officer to correct errors or make adjustments in the accounts of an insurance company outside the specific provisions of the Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The only other question is, Is there a general right to correct the errors in the accounts of an insurance company when assessing the income-tax? The High Court thought there was. We are wholly unable to agree with this view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10(7) and Schedule completely govern assessment overriding other sections; insurance accounts regulated by Insurance Act and Controller; no residual power.

holdings.text: The question referred to the High Court - whether ITO had jurisdiction to make adjustment under r.3(b) - is answered in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The question framed has to be answered in the negative. We would for this reason allow the appeals with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of rules shows no justification for adjustment.

holdings.text: The proviso to r.3(b) negatives any general power to adjust and action must be strictly per proviso or not at all.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: main rule mandatory on books, proviso exclusive for discrepancies; no independent general jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Prior cases under old r.30 not precedents as new r.3(b) materially altered by addition of proviso limiting powers.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative change via proviso restricts what old rule permitted.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the decision of the High Court is clearly erroneous. Under r. 2 of the Schedule the Income- tax Officer has to compute the profits and gains of a life insurance company at the greater of the two methods of assessments mentioned in cls. a and b . There may be no restriction upon his jurisdiction in the computation of profits and gains under cl. a but under cl. b the computation can be made within a limited field.
The question framed has to be answered in the negative. We would for this reason allow the appeals with costs.

edges.explanation: h2 holds adjustment not within main part of r.3(b), addressing jurisdiction under r.3(b) in i2

anchor.surface_text: When we come to r. 3 b we find that the first part of it lays down that it shall be obligatory on the Income-tax Officer to allow certain amounts written off or reserved by the assessee as a deduction and to include in the surplus any sums for which credit has been taken on account of appreciation or gains on the realisation of the securities or other assets.
The question framed has to be answered in the negative. We would for this reason allow the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the proviso in r. 3 b . It says that if it appears to the Income-tax Officer having regard to certain matters to which it is not necessary to refer here in detail, that the rate of interest or other factor employed in determining the liability in respect of outstanding policies is materially inconsistent with the valuation of the securities and other assets so as artificially to reduce the surplus,
The question framed has to be answered in the negative. We would for this reason allow the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The only other question is, Is there a general right to correct the errors in the accounts of an insurance company when assessing the income-tax? The High Court thought there was. We are wholly unable to agree with this view.
The question framed has to be answered in the negative. We would for this reason allow the appeals with costs.
